contentrichtext.text: In [[Greek mythology]], '''Elara''' was a mortal [[princess]], the daughter of King [[Orchomenus (mythology)|Orchomenus]] and mother of the giant [[Tityos]] by [[Zeus]]. == Myth == Zeus fell in love with Elara and hid her from his wife [[Hera]]'s jealousy by placing her deep beneath the [[Earth]]. This was where she gave birth to Tityos, a giant who is sometimes said to be the son of [[Gaia (mythology)|Gaia]], the [[Chthonic|Earth goddess]], for this reason. It is further added that Elara died in labour because of the enormous size of her baby.<ref>Pseudo-[[Apollodorus of Athens|Apollodorus]], ''[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Bibliotheca]]'' 1. 4. 2.</ref><ref>[[Scholia]] on [[Apollonius Rhodius]], ''Argonautica'', 1. 761</ref> The cave through which Tityos was believed to have come to the surface of Earth was located on [[Euboea]] and referred to as ''Elarion''.<ref>[[Strabo]], ''Geography'', 9. 3. 15</ref> == Eponymy == One moon of [[Jupiter]] is named [[Elara (moon)|Elara]].<ref name="IAUC 2846">{{cite journal| last=Marsden|first=B. G.|title=Satellites of Jupiter|journal=IAUC Circular |volume=2846|date=7 October 1974|url=http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iauc/02800/02846.html}}</ref> [[File:Elara2-LB1-mag17.jpg|[[Elara (moon)|Moon Elara]]|140px|thumb]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Elara (Mythology)}} [[Category:Greek mythology]] [[Category:Mortal parents of demigods in Classical mythology]] [[Category:Mortal women of Zeus]]
